Low key promotion seeks paying students
By ALAN HIRSCH
Hopkins admissions officers.
are in the process of launching a,
"low key" promotion campaign!
designed to increase the rate of
matriculation of paying
undergraduates.
The campaign is the result of a
10 percent drop in the
matriculation rate of students
not awarded financial aid last
year.
The admissions staff is
preparing a series of brochures
describing each area of study
here, in addition to general
literature about Hopkins. In
addition, the University is trying
to increase alumni participation
in the recruitment of students.
Director of Academic Services
Larry Denton stressed that the
increased promotion is
"definitely low key."
"We don't want a hard-sell
campaign," he said.
Hopkins has found it necessary
to increase its
promotion at this
time, Denton said, because the
college market is now "a buyer's
market."
According to Denton, virtually
any student who is academically
qualified and who can'apay his
own way can not attend any of
the "high-cost, bigname" schools
because these schools are in dire
need of money.
Of the students who a,.!
accepted without Financial Aid
to this year's Freshman Class,
only 30 percent decided to
attend Hopkins, as compared to
40 percent in the two preceeding
years.

At the same time, the
matriculation rate of students
offered Financial Aid last year
remained the same as in the past
few years—about 50 percent.
The impact of this shift in the
college market has thus far
neither hindered the University's
ability to attract sufficient
numbers of paying students nor
affected the quality of students"
admitted to the school, according
to Denton and Owen.
But, the shift has made it
difficult for Hopkins to achieve
academic diversification in its
student body, Denton said.
Denton explained that the
overwhelming majority of
applicants to Hopkins are
pre-meds, and that most of the
non-natural science applicants
who are qualified are accepted.

Consequently, if a significant
portion of the middle income
students who can "pay their own
way" continue to opt for other
schools over Hopkins the
University may find its rolls

glutted with Natural Science
Area majors and pre-meds,
Denton asserted.
"We want to make sure we get
our fair share of non pre-meds,"
Denton remarked.

Sellers is now doing Pan Am
commercials. It's a living.
The Goon Shows were never
very big over here. For one thing,
Americans don't generally get
British humor. The overt
inanities of the British wit goes
unappreciated by the American
mind, which is attuned to such
finer forms of funniness as
Pollack jokes and dead baby
one-liners. Another reason was
that it was only carried on BBC.
Monty Python's Flying Circus is
a bit more accessible. They are
on TV, although only PBS in the
states, records, and in the
cinema. Despite all the exposure,
they still do not have a popular
following, only a hip one.
They do extensive sketches on
Australia (which Americans, not
thinking the Australians the
ruffians that the British do, don't
get), like the one on Australian
table wines. A fairly drunk

announcer describes the wines in
such terms as, "it ranks with the
world's best mint-flavoured
burgundies'', or "Chateaur
Briande Wogga-Wogga, which has
a bouquet on it like an
aborigine's armpit."
Characters such as Mrs.
Premise am' Mrs. Conclusion,
lines like "Lemon curry'?", and
songs like Eric the Half-A-Bee are
legends in their own time. Or at
least they try to be. It isn't easy,
you know. Not many songs are
legends. I mean there are some
songs that are legends, in as much.
as they are songs with legends in
them. But that's not the same.
Anyway, in order to
understand them on TV, you've
almost got to be British. How
else would you understand the
Mary Thatcher jokes, the BBC
jokes, or the old ladies' dialects?
Not only that, but you need a
UHF receiver strong enough to
pick up WETA in Washington.
Although their records are
easy to find, the material on
them is excerpted from the TV
shows, and therefore still as
exclusive. One album, Matching
Tie and Handkerchief on Arista,
has three sides. Figure that.
Their films have eluded
popdom as well. The first one,
called And Now For Something
Completely Different was the
biggest sleeper since What's Up
Tiger Lilly? Actually not a film
at all, it was a collage of bits
from the TV show, complete
with the old opening (a BBC
voiced announcer saying "And
now for something completely
different," followed by the
theme—Sousa's Liberty Bell
March—and the animated
opening).
The second film, Monty
Python and the Holy Grail was
the real test. Despite the large
scale publicity, the film refused
to catch on. Penelope Gilliat
loved it. Rex Reed did not review
it; he sort of danced around it.
The Sun's R.H. Gardner
calculated that it was funny
"20% of the time"(one wonders
at the mind it must take to
compute a percentile humor
content). All in all, it could still
be hip to like Monty Python'.
Of course, there is probably
someone so hip that I have never
heard of him, just as surely as
there is probably some asshole
who will write in saying that
"Mel Brooks is too funny."

Some very crucial financial
issues face the University.
President Muller's current
contemplation of the size of an

questioning the economic
viability of private institutions.

of an intensive review of their
expenditures. In the summer of
1974 Muller had called for a zero
budgetary
policy to be
implemented in all administrative
offices in preparation for the
fiscal year 1976 budget. By this,
all cost outlays were to be
examined in their entirety, a
departure from previous methods
of budgetary analysis which
examined only the changes
planned in staff size and other
related expenses.
Crunch
In light of economic
exigencies, Muller's fiscal
r epsonsiveness
seemed to
anticipate the impending money
crunch which now finds Hopkins
in company with other private
i nstitutions struggling
to
maintain solvency. Muller also
saw fit then to
appoint an ad
hoc budgetary committee in the
fall, headed by Arts and Sciences
Faculty members Owen Phillips,
of Earth and Planetary Sciences,
and Carl Christ, of Political
Economy,

extremely difficult to assess the
costs and benefits of an'

become in recent years. Christ
now admits that coming to grips

extremely difficult task.

interesting statistics concerning
the growth of the administration

group found, for example, that
"General Services and

climbed from $3,312,000 in

$4,065,000 in 1973-74, while
student aid expanded only from
$3,147,000 to $3,191,000 in the
same time period.

expense items of questionable
necessity. Full-time salaried staff
at the personnel office for the
central administration jumped
from nine to fourteen between
1970 and 1974, while its
Homewood counterpart saw fit
to expand from eight to fourteen

in that interval.

figures shows that the Dean of
Students Office ballooned from
four full-time staff in 1970-71 to

eleven at the end of 1974.
It is becoming increasingly
necessary for students and
faculty here to raise questions
concerning this type of

administrative expenditure in the
presence of a strapped economy.

to demonstrate the need for such
wholesale addition to their staff.
